title-group.article-title: Thermal and chemical treatments of recycled carbon fibres for improved adhesion to polymeric matrix

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Engineering for Innovation, University of Salento, Italy
2Technical Unit for Brindisi Material Technologies (UTTMATB), Brindisi Research Centere, Brindisi, Italy
3Technical Unit for Trisaia Technologies (UTTRI), Trisaia Research Centre, Rotondella, Italy

author-notes.corresp: Antonio Greco, Department of Engineering for Innovation, University of Salento, via per Arnesano, Lecce 73100, Italy. Email: antonio.greco@unisalento.it

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The aim of this study is the characterization of recycled carbon fibres, in view of their potential application in long-fibre reinforced thermoplastic composite. The fibres were obtained from epoxy matrix composite panels, applying a patented process that includes the pyrolisis of the matrix followed by an upgrading of the fibres. Then, recycled fibres were further subjected to thermal and acid treatments in order to modify their surface morphology and chemistry. Scanning electron microscopy and energy dispersive spectrometry were used to characterize the morphological and compositional changes of the fibre surface. The fibres were characterized in terms of mechanical properties and adhesion to an epoxy matrix. The fibres treated by thermal processes at high temperatures (600°C) were shown to be too severely damaged, making them unsuitable for the production of fibre-reinforced composites. A thermal treatment at lower temperatures (450°C) involved a very limited damaging without any evident chemical modification of the fibre surface, which in turn involved a limited increase of the adhesion properties to an epoxy matrix. Chemical treatment by nitric acid caused a very limited damage of fibres, coupled with a significant modification of surface chemistry, which in turn involved a further increase of the fibre/matrix adhesion properties.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In recent years, the increasing use of carbon fibre reinforced polymers has raised the relevant question of their recycling. Both environmental and economic considerations push towards the development of innovative technologies to reuse the carbon fibre reinforced plastics (CFRPs). Nowadays, the increase of the sustainability and recycling capability of CFRPs is one of the major goals of the composite industry.1

The economic value of CFRPs makes recycling of particular relevance. In 2007 and 2008, the global consumption of carbon fibres was estimated to be about 27,000 and 35,000 tons, respectively. A further growth rate of 12% per year leads to a projection of a consumption of 70,000 tons in 2014. About 20% of the CFRP market is represented by the aeronautic productions of Airbus and Boeing.2 The global capacity of the carbon fibre production plants has grown from 36,170 tons in 2007 to 62,567 tons in 2010.3 Nowadays, the main source of CFRP waste is given by manufacturing scraps.4 End-of-life CFRP waste is expected to grow exponentially, due to decommissioning of aircrafts incorporating CFRP parts. Therefore, it is expected that in the next few years, the CFRP waste coming from the end-of-life components will significantly contribute to the global CFRP waste.

The disposal of CFRPs and/or of the carbon fibre reinforcements (in the form of filaments, fabrics, etc.) through landfill or incineration is no longer a suitable solution, due to legislative, economic and environmental reasons. The recent legislation imposes upon the automotive and electronic industries that new products must be recoverable or recyclable, severely limiting the amount of materials which can be disposed in landfill.5 It is reasonable to think that in the next few years, similar procedures will be adopted for the aeronautic industry, where CFRPs are going to be largely used. It is clear that turning CFRP waste into a valuable resource and closing the loop in the CFRP lifecycle is vital for the continued use of these materials. This need has driven not only research on recycling processes for composites over the last 15 years,6,7 but also the formation of several collaborative entities working at an industrial level.

Focusing on thermoset matrix composites, which absorb the greater amount of the carbon fibre reinforced composite market, the crosslinked nature of the resin does not allow for any recycling procedure by reprocessing.4 The recycling technologies can be divided into three families: mechanical recycling, i.e. machining aimed at the production of fillers,8 thermal treatments and chemical processes. In the latter, the matrix can be cracked into low molecular weight compounds9 or dissolved in solvents,10 or extracted by supercritical fluids.11 The thermal treatments include pyrolisis,12 gasification13 and fluid bed.14 Most of the developed approaches have remained on a laboratory-scale level, and only the pyrolisis-based treatments are reaching the commercial-scale level. Only recently, the recycling processes have been patented,15–17 and the commercial and economic feasibility of CFRP recycling has drawn the attention of the industry, for instance KARBOREK S.p.a and Recycled Carbon Fibre Ltd. In particular, the ENEA (Italian agency for atomic and renewable energies and the environment) patent15 describes the process of recycling of CFRP components at the end of their service life, with the aim of recovering the carbon fibres. The process is made of two different stages, the first one devoted to resin pyrolisis and the second one fibre surface upgrading by removal of residual char. The two phases can take place in the same reactor. Figure 1 shows a schematic of the process, in which the two phases of pyrolisis and upgrading are highlighted. The process can be carried out by different technologies, including conveyor belt, rotating drum or fluidized bed. Pyrolisis must be run in nitrogen with a programmed heating ramp up to 250–550°C, followed by an isothermal treatment of about 20 min. The upgrading phase occurs in a reactive gas mixture (CO2, O2, air and water vapour) in order to remove char, still preserving the surface of carbon fibres from degradation. The upgrading stage is usually run between 550°C and 700°C, with a holding time of about 1–2 h. Figure 1.
Schematic of the CFRP recycling process developed at ENEA.15 CFRP: carbon fibre reinforced plastic.

The aim of this article is the characterization of recovered carbon fibres obtained by the process patented by ENEA, in view of their application in moulding compounds. After recovering, the fibres were treated using thermal oxidation and nitric acid exposure, in order to improve their adhesion to polymeric matrices. The properties of recycled carbon fibres (RCFs), characterized by tensile testing, single-fibre fragmentation tests (SFFTs) and scanning electron microscopic (SEM) analysis, were compared to those of the corresponding virgin fibres.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: The virgin fibres used for comparison purposes are commercially available from Torayca, as T800S and are characterized by a tensile strength of 5.9 GPa, tensile modulus 295 GPa, density 1.8 g/cm3 and an average diameter 6 µm.

RCFs were recovered from specimens of cured carbon fibre/epoxy composite material. The specimens were fabricated using pre-impregnated unidirectional carbon fibre/epoxy of type T800S/3900 (nominal diameter 6 µm), produced by Toray Composites America.

The composite scraps were processed using the process patented by ENEA which includes pyrolisis for 20 min at 500°C followed by 90 min at 550°C for the mentioned upgrading treatment. Fibres with an average length of 50 mm with random orientation were obtained and have been referred below as RCF.

sec.title: Modification of RCFs
sec.p:
In order to improve the adhesion properties of recycled fibres to polymeric matrices, the recycled fibre surfaces were further modified by oxidative thermal or acid treatments:18–21
90 min in air at 450°C (ample code RCF450);
90 min in air at 600°C (sample code RCF600); and
immersion in HNO3 solution at 5% for 30 min at 100°C (sample code RCFacid).
The HNO3 treatment was performed by adding 7 g of fibres in 50 mL of HNO3 solution followed by drying and an additional washing with distilled water to remove any residual acidity.

sec.title: Characterization
sec.p: Single-filament tensile tests were performed according to ASTM 3379 using a TA Instruments ARES. A single filament was bonded on a cardboard using 10 and 20 mm gauge length, which was then clamped between tools. Tensile tests, 30 repetitions for each sample, were performed at a constant crosshead rate of 0.002 mm/min on sample lengths of 10 and 20 mm. In order to quantify the effect of the treatment on the mechanical behaviour of the fibres, both modulus and strength were calculated using a nominal value of the diameter of 6 µm for all the samples. This allows to establish a direct comparison of the load-bearing capability between the treated and the virgin fibres.

The results of tensile tests performed at different sample lengths were interpreted by Weibull statistical approach22,23 (1)ln(ln(11-F))=βln(σ)-βln(σ0)+ln(ALf) where σ is the tensile strength of individual filaments, F the failure probability, A the filament cross section, Lf the sample length and σ0 and β fitting parameters.
The failure probability, F, was obtained by experimental tensile strength data by a median-order approach as:24 (2)F=i-0.3N+0.4 where i is the ith of N total number of tests.

Fitting of experimental data, and determination of the fitting parameters, allowed for the determination of the strength σ0.5* corresponding to a breaking probability F = 0.5 for the fibres of length l*. Then, the strength for the same value of probability at different fibre lengths can be obtained as25 (3)σ0.5(l)=(l*l)1/βσ0.5*

The SFFT26 was performed in order to measure the fibre/matrix interfacial shear strength (IFSS) using the shear-lag model developed by Kelly–Tyson27,28 (4)IFSS=σ0.5(LC)d2LC where d is the fibre diameter and σf (LC) is the fibre strength calculated in correspondence of the critical length of the filaments, (LC, according to equation (3). A single fibre was embedded along the centre line of a silicon rubber mould with dog-bone-shaped cavity. A cycloaliphatic epoxy resin ACCUGEN 100 by 3D Systems, characterized by an adequately high transparency and elongation at break (about 4.6%), was degassed under vacuum and casted into the cavity of the silicon mould. The tensile tests were performed on a LLOYD LR5K dynamometer, equipped with a loading cell of 1000 N, using a crosshead speed of 2 mm/min. After sample failure, an optical microscope was used for measuring the length of the resulting fibre fragments. The critical length LC was related to the average length of broken fragments as29–31 (5)LC=43L
SEM analysis was performed on a Zeiss EVO 40 instrument equipped with energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) for elemental analysis.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
A SEM micrograph of the carbon fibres subjected to the pyrolisis treatment for 20 min at 500°C is reported in Figure 2(a), showing the presence of a significant amount of char, which is expected to negatively affect the adhesion properties to polymeric materials in the production of composite with recycled fibres. The SEM micrograph of RCF obtained after the upgrading process in air for 90 min at 550°C is reported in Figure 2(b), where a smooth surface, resulting from an almost complete removal of the char from their surfaces, is obtained. The fibres are characterized by an average diameter of 6.2 ± 0.03 µm, as also reported in Table 1. Figure 2.
SEM micrography of carbon fibres after: (a) pyrolisis and (b) upgrading processes. SEM: scanning electron microscopy. Table 1.
Diameter and O/C ratio of RCF and treated RCF
Label O/C ratio Oxygen % weight on fibre surface
RCF 6.20 5.04
RCF450 5.58 5.20
RCF600 3.32 9.02
RCFacid 5.39 10.1
O/C ratio: oxygen to carbon ratio and RCF: recycled carbon fibre.

The results of SEM analysis performed on recycled fibres subjected to different conditioning treatments are reported in Figure 3. The oxidizing thermal treatment at 450°C (sample RCF450, Figure 3(a)) involves a slight reduction in fibre diameter to about 5.58 µm (Table 1) and some damaging of the surface of the fibres. Fibre damaging is much more significant when the treatment temperature is raised to 600°C, as shown in Figure 3(b) for sample RCF600. In addition, fibres treated at 600°C show a dramatic reduction in diameter to about 3.32 µm (Table 1). The treatment with nitric acid involves a moderate decrease in diameter to 5.39 µm. The EDS analysis results are also reported in Table 1. The oxygen amount measured on the RCF surface is about 5% by weight and is not significantly modified by the thermal treatment at 450°C. This indicates that chemical modifications of the surface composition of fibres are not relevant when oxidation is run at 450°C. On the other hand, the oxygen amount on the fibre surface is increased to about 9% when the fibres are oxidized at 600°C and to about 10.1% after treatment with nitric acid. The values obtained for the oxygen amount of fibre RCFacid are in very good agreement with literature data,18 reporting an oxygen amount about 12% after nitric acid treatment. Figure 3.
SEM images of sample: (a) RCF450; (b) RCF600; and (c) RCFacid. SEM: scanning electron microscopy.

Therefore, both treatments involve a significant oxidation of the fibre surface. In contrast, thermal treatment at 600°C also involves a significant damaging, including the development of local defects and a significant increase of the surface roughness, whereas nitric acid treatment is only responsible of a limited damaging.

The values of tensile modulus obtained from mechanical characterization of single filaments are reported in Figure 4. The RCF shows a slight reduction of modulus (about 8%) compared to virgin fibres, and the modulus is not significantly influenced by the length of the fibres. The difference between the 10- and 20-mm long fibres is lower than the error bars, indicating that the difference between the two samples can be attributed to the experimental error. In the case of the RCF450 and RCFacid, the modulus is not affected by the treatment or fibre length. Also in this case, the differences between the different samples are well within the error bars associated to the tests. On the other hand, the sample RCF600 shows a significant reduction of modulus, which is about 42% of the value measured for RCF. In this case, the modulus decrease can be attributed to the reduced diameter of the fibres resulting from the oxidizing thermal treatment at 600°C. Even in the case of sample RCF600, there is no significant effect of the fibre length on the modulus. Figure 4.
Tensile modulus of single-filament recycled fibres.

The values of the tensile strength for the different fibres are reported in Figure 5. The 10-mm long RCFs are characterized by a tensile strength very close to that reported in the technical data sheet of the virgin fibres. The oxidizing thermal treatment at 450°C is responsible of irrelevant changes of the strength, since the differences between sample RCF and RCF450 fall in between the standard deviation. On the other hand, fibres treated at 600°C are characterized by a dramatic decrease in strength, which is reduced to about 34% of the strength of RCF. The strength decrease is much more signifcant compared to that of the modulus, as a consequence of the presence of a large amount of defects at the thermally oxidized surface of fibres. The reults obtained on sample RCF600 indicate that the treatment conditions are too harsh. Nitric acid exposure is less aggressive, leading to strength properties comparable to those of the sample RCF450. The strength of the fibres treated in nitric acid is about 75–80% of the strength of fibre RCF, as already found by other authors.32 Figure 5.
Tensile strength of single-filament recycled fibres.

A comparison between the samples of different lengths shows that the 20-mm long fibres are characterized by a lower tensile strength compared to 10-mm long fibres. This is in agreement with the Weibull statistics analysis, as it results from equation (1). The effect of the treatment of fibres on the tensile strength of 20-mm long fibres is similar to that previously discussed for 10-mm long fibres, being the treatment at 600°C the most severe and the one at 450°C the less damage-bearing.

The results reported in Figures 4 and 5 are confirmed by one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) analysis33 performed on samples of different lengths. With two factor levels (fibres of different lengths) and 29 degrees of freedom for each level, (30 tests on each level), it is possible to estimate a critical value of the F-ratio (Fcv(1,58)) equal to four at a significance level α = 0.05. The F-ratio values calculated for the tensile modulus are 1.43, 0.526, 1.24 and 2.53 for samples RCF, RCF450, RCF600 and RCFacid, respectively. In all cases, the value of the F-ratio is much lower than Fcv(1,58) which indicates that differences are not relevant at the 5% significance level. On the other hand, the F-ratio calculated for the tensile strength are 10.03, 47.98, 130.31 and 27.38, respectively, which indicates that differences between fibres of different lengths are relevant at the 5% significance level.

Two-way ANOVA33 was also performed on the experimental data of tensile modulus and tensile strength, selecting the fibre length as factor 1 and the fibre treatment as factor 2. Results obtained for the tensile modulus are summarized in Table 2, showing that at the 5% significance level, the differences within fibres of different lengths are not statistically significant. On the other hand, Table 2 shows that the modulus of samples subjected to different treatments are statistically different. Also, evaluation of the interaction parameter shows that the difference between fibres subjected to different treatments is independent of the fibre length. The ANOVA results obtained for tensile strength are reported in Table 3, showing that both factors, fibre length and fibre treatment, have a dramatic influence on the tensile strength. Also, the interaction F-ratio is equal to 3.18, which is a value higher than the critical value of F(3,232) = 2.6, indicating that at the 5% significance level, the fibre treatment has a specific role for different lengths. Table 2.
Two-way ANOVA analysis results for tensile modulus
Sample Degrees of freedom Mean square F
Factor 1(fibre length) 1 270 0.518
Factor 2(fibre treatment) 3 1.47E5 281
Interaction 3 987 1.89
Error 232 521
ANOVA: analysis of variance.
Table 3.
Two-way ANOVA analysis results for tensile strength
Sample Degrees of freedom Mean square F
Factor 1(fibre length) 1 3.18E7 104
Factor 2(fibre treatment) 3 6.44E7 211
Interaction 3 9.74E5 3.18
Error 232 3.06E5
ANOVA: analysis of variance.

Weibull statistics was applied to each sample group by plotting ln(ln(11-F)) versus ln (σ). Linear fitting was used, according to equation (1), for the calculation of the parameters σ0 and β. Typical plots, with the corresponding linear-fitting procedure, are reported in Figures 6 and 7 for samples RCF and RCF450, respectively. The Weibull parameters of the four samples are reported in Table 2, showing that the shape factor β decreases when the surface damage of the fibres increases. Therefore, comparing the results of Figure 5 and Table 4, it is possible to observe the direct correlation between the level of damage and defect accumulation on the fibres and the value of β, indicating an increased brittleness arising from the larger number of defects produced by these treatments.34 Figure 6.
Weibull plot for sample RCF. RCF: recycled carbon fibre. Figure 7.
Weibull plot for sample RCF450. Table 4.
Weibull parameters for recovered and treated carbon fibres
Label β σ0
RCF 10.9 2020
RCF450 8.18 1740
RCF600 5.42 250
RCFacid 6.82 1155
RCF: recycled carbon fibre.

Once the value of β is known, it is possible to plot the fibre strength as a function of the fibre length for a value of F = 0.5. The results obtained for RCF are reported in Figure 8, showing a very good agreement between experimental data and Weibull model prediction. Figure 8.
Tensile strength versus fibre length for RCF fibres at S = 0.5. RCF: recycled carbon fibre.

A typical picture obtained after SFFT is reported in Figure 9 for the sample RCFacid. For each sample, the average length of broken segments (lm) was determined from optical microscopy. Then, the strength of the fibres in correspondence of the length lC was calculated according to equation (3). An example of the procedure for RCFs is reported in Figure 8. Finally, the IFSS was calculated from equation (4). Figure 9.
Optical image of RCFacid sample after SFFT. SFFT: single-fibre fragmentation test.

The results from SFFT tests, reported in Table 5, show that the sample RCF450 has an IFSS which is about 40% higher than that of RCF. An increase in IFSS can be associated either to a ‘physical’ effect, related to fibre roughness and increased friction between fibre and matrix, or a ‘chemical’ effect, related to the modification of the surface chemistry of fibres. In the case of RCF450, since no relevant modification of the surface chemistry of fibres was observed, the increase in IFSS is attributed to an increased fibre roughness resulting from thermal treatment, as shown in Figure 3(a). The fibres treated with nitric acid show an even higher value of IFSS. The increase of the IFSS is comparable to those found by other authors on virgin carbon fibres treated in nitric acid.18 Table 5.
SFFT results for recovered and treated carbon fibres
Sample lm (mm) lC (mm) σf (MPa) IFSS (MPa)
RCF 0.94 ± 0.30 1.26 ± 0.40 6480 12.9 ± 3.10
RCF450 0.81 ± 0.29 1.08 ± 0.39 7760 18.00 ± 4.74
RCFacid 0.62 ± 0.09 0.83 ± 0.12 7110 21.50 ± 2.72
SFFT: single-fibre fragmentation test; IFSS: interfacial shear strength; and RCF: recycled carbon fibre.

Since these fibres are characterized by mechanical properties only slightly lower than those of sample RCF450 (Figure 5), and therefore by a slightly higher levels of density of surface defects (Figure 3(c)), it can be concluded that the acid treatment also introduces additional polarity that improves the adhesion to the epoxy matrix. The high brittleness of the sample RCF650 made the performance of SFFT testing impossible.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this article, the mechanical properties of RCFs and their adhesion to an epoxy matrix were studied. The recovered fibres were produced by a patented process, involving at first the pyrolisis of the thermoset matrix followed by an upgrading of the fibres. The recovered fibres were shown to have mechanical properties comparable to those of the virgin fibres. Nevertheless, the removal of the sizing during the pyrolisis process was responsible of a very limited adhesion of the fibres with an epoxy matrix. For this reason, the recycled fibres were further treated by oxidizing thermal and acid treatments. Fibres treated at 600°C show a significant reduction in diameter, coupled with a relevant increase of oxygen content at the surface. However, the severe damaging of fibres treated at 600°C was responsible of a drastic decrease in their mechanical properties. The oxidizing thermal treatment at 450°C did not involve any significant modification of the surface chemistry and had a very limited mechanical damage. Consequently, the mechanical properties of the fibres were almost unmodified compared to untreated fibres. Therefore, the observed increase in the IFSS for the RCF450 fibres can be entirely attributed to mechanical friction between fibres and matrix. The chemical treatment involved a significant improvement of fibre/matrix adhesion without compromising the fibre strength and modulus. The additional increase of IFSS compared to sample RCF450 was attributed to the oxygen enrichment of the fibre surface, making this kind of treatment the most promising for the production of RCF composites.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

sec.title: Conflicts of interest
sec.p: None declared.
